definition:
*Complete lattice homomorphism* is a function from one lattice to an
other lattice, which preserves arbitrary (not only finite) meets and
joins.

If $\phi:L \to M$ is lattice homomorphism between complete lattices $L$
and $M$ such that

-   $\phi(\bigvee \lbrace a_i\mid i\in I\rbrace) = \bigvee \lbrace \phi(a_i)\mid
    i\in I\rbrace$, and

-   $\phi(\bigwedge \lbrace a_i\mid i\in I\rbrace) = \bigwedge \lbrace
    \phi(a_i)\mid i\in I\rbrace$,

then $\phi$ is called a *complete lattice homomorphism*.

Most often are considered *complete lattice homomorphisms* from one
complete lattice to an other complete lattice (that is when all meets
and joins are defined).

*Complete lattice homomorphism* is a special case of lattice
homomorphism.
